content.description:
Climb the crack splitting the obvious slab on the climber's left side of this area.  Use the large, fun features (mostly edges and horizontal cracks with big pods) around the crack as well.  It's easier to start on these features to the left of the crack and work up to the crack for your first placement.  There are two topout variations.  The first is to continue straight up using two parallel cracks that come off of the large, vegetated ledge the crack goes into.  The second is to traverse right around the bulge to the right of this ledge and slab climb up after the bulge is past.  The right variation is technically easier, the left is easier to protect.

If you've never done trad before, it's a great route to learn/practice on.  You're always in a stable stance (or, if you're not, you're doing something wrong), so you can practice easy, uncommitting slab and crack moves with solid crack placements all the way up.



The obvious slab on the far left of the Middle Ground.  It can easily be seen from the Main Face bouldering routes on the left side of that area.

Medium to smaller cams or large passive pro.
After the Main Face peters out, there is a bouldering wall slightly offset uphill from it and a large, obvious slab to the left of and slightly separated from this wall.
